column1: The earliest known human inhabitants of what is now Delray Beach were the Jaega people. Tequesta Indians likely passed through or inhabited the area at various times
column2: and an 1841 U.S. military map shows a Seminole camp located in the area now known as Lake Ida. Few other recorded details of these local indigenous settlements have survived.In 1876
column3: the United States Life Saving Service built the Orange Grove House of Refuge to rescue and shelter ship-wrecked sailors. The house derived its name from the grove of mature sour orange and other tropical fruit trees found at the site chosen for the house of refuge
column4: but no record or evidence of who planted the trees was discovered.

column1: The first non-indigenous group to build a settlement was a party of African Americans from the panhandle of Florida
column2: who purchased land a little inland from the Orange Grove House of Refuge and began farming around 1884. By 1894 the black community was large enough to establish the first school in the area.In 1894 William S. Linton
column3: a Republican U.S. Congressman for Saginaw
column5: bought a tract of land just west of the Orange Grove House of Refuge
column6: and began selling plots in what he hoped would become a farming community. Initially
column7: this community was named after Linton. In 1896 Henry Flagler extended his Florida East Coast Railroad south from West Palm Beach to Miami
column8: with a station at Linton.The Linton settlers established a post office and a store
column9: and began to achieve success with truck farming of winter vegetables for the northern market. A hard freeze in 1898 was a setback
column10: and many of the settlers left
column11: including William Linton. Partly in an attempt to change the community's luck
column12: or to leave behind a bad reputation
column13: the settlement's name was changed in 1901 to Delray
column14: after the Detroit neighborhood of Delray ("Delray" being the anglicized spelling of "Del Rey"
column15: which is Spanish for "of the king")
column16: which in turn was named after the Mexican–American War's Battle of Molino del Rey.Settlers from The Bahamas (then part of the British West Indies)
column18: began arriving in the early 1900s. After 1905
column19: newspaper articles and photographs of Delray events reveal that Japanese settlers from the nearby Yamato farming colony also began participating in Delray civic activities such as parades
column21: and shopping. The 1910 census shows Delray as a town of 904 citizens. Twenty-four U.S. states and nine other countries are listed as the birthplace of its residents. Although still a small town
column22: Delray had a remarkably diverse citizenry.In 1911
column23: the area was chartered by the State of Florida as an incorporated town. In the same year
column24: pineapple and tomato canning plants were built. Pineapples became the primary crop of the area. This is reflected in the name of the present day Pineapple Grove neighborhood near downtown Delray Beach.Prior to 1909
column25: the Delray settlement land was within Dade County. That year
column26: Palm Beach County was carved out of the northern portion of the region. In 1915
column27: Palm Beach County and Dade County contributed nearly equal portions of land to create what is now Broward County between the two
column28: leaving Delray situated within the southeastern portion of Palm Beach County.By 1920
column31: drainage of the Everglades west of Delray lowered the water table
column32: making it harder to grow pineapples
column33: while the extension of the Florida East Coast Railway to Key West resulted in competition from Cuban pineapples for the markets of the northern United States.The Florida land boom of the 1920s brought renewed prosperity to Delray. Tourism and real estate speculation became important parts of the local economy. Delray issued bonds to raise money to install water and sewer lines
column35: and sidewalks. Several hotels were built. At that time Delray was the largest town on the east coast of Florida between West Palm Beach and Fort Lauderdale. The collapse of the land boom in 1926 left Delray saddled with high bond debts
column36: and greatly reduced income from property taxes.Delray was separated from the Atlantic Ocean beach by the Florida East Coast Canal (now part of the Intracoastal Waterway). In 1923 the area between the canal and the ocean was incorporated as Delray Beach. In 1927 Delray and Delray Beach merged into one town named Delray Beach.

column2: a seasonal Artists and Writers Colony was established in Delray Beach and the adjacent town of Gulf Stream. At the time
column3: the city of Palm Beach did not welcome Hollywood personalities or all types of artists
column4: so the Delray winter colony drew a more eclectic and bohemian populace. Throughout the 1930s and '40s
column5: Delray became a popular winter enclave for artists and authors
column6: especially famous cartoonists. Two nationally syndicated cartoonists – H. T. Webster (creator of "Caspar Milquetoast") and Fontaine Fox of "Toonerville Trolley" fame – had offices upstairs in the Arcade Building over the Arcade Tap Room; a gathering place where the artists and writers might be joined by aristocrats
column9: and sports figures. Other well-known artists and writers of the era who had homes in Delray Beach include: Herb Roth
column20: and Edna St. Vincent Millay. These seasonal visitors helped soften the effect of the real estate downturn and The Great Depression on the city.During the Depression
column21: not much money was available since the two banks had failed
column23: and the town still looked prosperous because of the previous burst of new buildings during the boom years. The Artists and Writers Colony flourished and Delray Beach's fame as a resort town grew. This era is regarded as Delray Beach's "golden age of architecture;" a period in which the city ranked 50th in population but 10th in building permits in Florida. Prominent architectural styles in Delray Beach from this period include Art Deco
column29: and 'Key West style' cottage homes for the Artists and Writers Colony winter residents.

column1: For the four years of World War II
column2: citizens of Delray Beach volunteered to watch the beach and ocean 24 hours a day from the faux bell tower atop the seaside Seacrest Hotel. Military personnel patrolled the beach on horseback. Shipping attacks could be seen from the coast. During WWII Delray Beach also saw an influx of service personnel stationed at the nearby Boca Raton Army Airfield. Some of the veterans who had trained at the airfield returned to settle in Delray Beach after the war. Steady growth of the city continued through the 1950s and 1960s.While Delray Beach had a sizeable African-American population from the beginning
column3: it attempted to keep out Jews. In 1959
column4: the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith called it "one of the nation's most completely anti-Semitic communities". It quoted an unnamed realtor who "proudly called it the only city on the East Coast [of Florida] fully restricted to Gentiles both in buying and selling".By the early 1960s Delray Beach was becoming known for surfing. Atlantic Avenue was the biggest seller of surfboards in Florida at the time. Delray Beach's surfing fame increased somewhat serendipitously after a 1965 shipwreck. During Hurricane Betsy
column5: the 441 feet (134 m) freighter Amaryllis ran aground on Singer Island
column6: creating a windbreak that formed perfectly breaking waves. The ship was dismantled three years later
column7: yet local surfers have retained an association with the area.In the 1970s
column8: Interstate 95 between Palm Beach Gardens and Miami was fully completed and development began to spread west of the city limits. This pattern continued and accelerated through the 1980s
column9: as downtown and many of the older neighborhoods fell into a period of economic decline.Revitalization of some historic areas began during the last decade of the twentieth century
column10: as several local landmark structures were renovated. These include the Colony Hotel and Old School Square (the former campus of Delray Elementary School and Delray High School
column11: since turned into a cultural center). The city also established five Historic Districts
column12: listed in the Local Register of Historic Places
column13: and annexed several other historic residential neighborhoods between U.S. Route 1 and the Intracoastal Waterway in an effort to preserve some of the distinctive local architecture.In 2001
column14: the historic home of teacher/principal Solomon D. Spady was renovated and turned into the Spady Cultural Heritage Museum. The Spady Museum houses black archives. In 2007 the museum was expanded by renovating a 1935 cottage as a Kid's Cultural Clubhouse

column1: Delray Beach has experienced a drastic spike in opioid overdoses in recent years
column2: reaching record numbers in 2016 and 2017. The number reached its pinnacle of 96 in October 2016. Most overdoses are a result of heroin mixed with Fentanyl.

column1: The city's eastern boundary includes 3 miles (4.8 km) of beachfront along the Atlantic Ocean.

column2: the city is bordered by Boca Raton.
the city is bordered by Highland Beach on the same barrier island east of the Intracoastal Waterway.
the city is bordered by Boynton Beach.
the city is bordered by Gulf Stream on the barrier island and along a section of mainland east of U.S. Route 1.
an urbanized area that includes High Point

column5: and multiple gated communities extends from the city's western boundary to the Loxahatchee National Wildlife Refuge portion of the Everglades. Many residences and businesses within this suburban corridor of unincorporated Palm Beach County possess a Delray Beach postal address despite technically lying outside the city limits. This area is sometimes referred to collectively and informally as "West Delray."Delray Beach's location in Southeastern Palm Beach County is in the middle of Florida's Gold Coast region.According to the United States Census Bureau
column6: the city of Delray Beach has a total land area of 15.81 miles (25.44 km).

column1: In earlier years downtown Delray was centered along Atlantic Avenue as far west as Swinton Avenue and as far east as the intracoastal waterway. Downtown has since expanded. By 2010
column2: downtown extended west to I-95 and east as the Atlantic Ocean; The north–south boundaries extend roughly two blocks north and south of Atlantic Avenue.

column1: Delray Beach has a tropical climate
column2: more specifically a tropical trade-wind rainforest climate (Köppen climate classification Af)
column3: as its driest month (February) averages 64.8mm of precipitation
column4: meeting the minimum standard of 60mm in the driest month needed to qualify for that designation.Delray Beach has hot and humid summers. High summertime temperatures range from 87-93 °F with low temperatures around 75-78 °F. Winters are warm
column5: with a marked drier season. Typical wintertime high temperatures are typically in the range of 74-83 °F and low temperatures 57-65 °F. However
column6: when occasional cold fronts hit South Florida
column7: daytime high temperatures may only reach the low or mid 60s (°F). Overnight lows during these brief periods can sink into the 40s. These cold fronts do not typically last more than a day or two and only occur several times each winter. Its near sea-level elevation
column9: position just above the Tropic of Cancer
column10: and proximity to the Gulf Stream shapes its climate. Hurricane season officially runs from June 1 through November 30
column11: although hurricanes can develop outside those dates. The most likely time for hurricane activity is during the peak of the Cape Verde season
column12: which is mid-August through the end of September. Delray Beach has received direct or near direct hits from hurricanes in 1903

column1: Downtown Delray Beach has had a building boom since roughly 2003. Recent development reflects trends of New Urbanism downtown
column2: and mansionization of waterfront property

column9: published investigative reports detailing fraud allegations within South Florida's billion-dollar drug rehab industry
column10: focusing on Delray Beach's sober houses. At least 30 arrests for illegal "patient brokering" had been made between July 2016 and July 2017 and more are expected.
